Population

​
The table gives the population, in millions, of a certain region for selected years. An exponential regression of the form <math alttext="f open parentheses x close parentheses equals a times b to the power of x"><semantics><mrow><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>·</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> is calculated for the five data points, where <math alttext="x equals 4"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> represents 2004 and <math alttext="x equals 8"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> represents 2008. Based on using the model <math alttext="f"><semantics><mi>f</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> to predict the future population, in what year will the population first reach <math alttext="35"><semantics><mn>35</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> million?

topic.text: 2.5: Exponential Function Context and Data Modeling
